You heal the target {@dice 1d4+4} hit points for a 1st-level spell slot, plus an additional {@dice 2d4} for each spell level higher than 1st, to a maximum of {@dice 7d4+4} hit points.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take the same Fighting Style option more than once, even if you get to choose again.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By 2nd level, you have learned to draw on divine magic through meditation and prayer to cast spells as a cleric does. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter paladin spell list|spells|class=Paladin (THICC)}.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Paladin table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter paladin spells|spells|class=Paladin (THICC)}. To cast one of your paladin spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of paladin spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the paladin spell list. When you do so, choose a number of paladin spells equal to your Charisma modifier + half your paladin level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 5th-level paladin, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With a Charisma of 14, your list of prepared spells can include four spells of 1st or 2nd-level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell cure wounds|phb}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or a 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of paladin spells requires time spent in prayer and meditation: ten minutes at the beginning of the day after a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your paladin spells, since their power derives from the strength of your convictions. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a paladin spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item holy symbol|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your paladin spells. A {@item holy symbol|phb} on your armor functions as a Material component, but not a Somatic component.
A {@item holy symbol|phb} on a weapon or shield functions as both Material and Somatic Components.

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: Your oath allows you to channel divine energy to fuel magical effects. Each Channel Divinity option provided by your oath explains how to use it.
When you use your Channel Divinity, you choose which option to use. You must then finish a short or long rest to use your Channel Divinity again.
Some Channel Divinity effects require saving throws. When you use such an effect from this class, the DC equals your paladin spell save DC.

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Harness Divine Power
entries: {@i 3rd-level paladin {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

You can expend a use of your Channel Divinity to fuel your spells. As a bonus action, you touch your holy symbol, utter a prayer, and regain one expended spell slot, the level of which can be no higher than half your proficiency bonus (rounded up). The number of times you can use this feature is based on the level you've reached in this class: 3rd level, once; 7th level, twice; and 15th level, thrice. You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Divine Health
entries: By 3rd level, the divine magic flowing through you makes you have advantage on saving throws against being diseased or {@condition poisoned|phb}, as well as resistance to poison damage.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you swear the oath that binds you as a paladin forever. Up to this time you have been in a preparatory stage, committed to the path but not yet sworn to it. Now you choose from the list of available oaths.
Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 15th, and 20th level. Those features include oath spells and the Channel Divinity feature.

entries.name: Oath Spells
entries: Each oath has a list of associated spells. You gain access to these spells at the levels specified in the oath description. Once you gain access to an oath spell, you always have it prepared. Oath spells don't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.
If you gain an oath spell that doesn't appear on the paladin spell list, the spell is nonetheless a paladin spell for you.

entries.name: Breaking Your Oath
entries: A paladin tries to hold to the highest standards of conduct, but even the most virtuous paladin is fallible. Sometimes the right path proves too demanding, sometimes a situation calls for the lesser of two evils, and sometimes the heat of emotion causes a paladin to transgress his or her oath.

A paladin who has broken a vow typically seeks absolution from a cleric who shares his or her faith or from another paladin of the same order. The paladin might spend an all-night vigil in prayer as a sign of penitence, or undertake a fast or similar act of self-denial. After a rite of confession and forgiveness, the paladin starts fresh.

If a paladin willfully violates his or her oath and shows no sign of repentance, the consequences can be more serious. At the DM's discretion, an impenitent paladin might be forced to abandon this class and adopt another, or perhaps to take the Oathbreaker paladin option that appears in the Dungeon Master's Guide.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Martial Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level paladin {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace a {@filter fighting style|optionalfeatures|feature type=FS:P} you know with another fighting style available to paladins. This replacement represents a shift of focus in your martial practice.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Aura of Protection
entries: Starting at 6th level, whenever you or a friendly creature within 10 feet of you must make a saving throw, the creature gains a bonus to the saving throw equal to your Charisma modifier (with a minimum bonus of +1). You must be conscious to grant this bonus.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Sacred Oath.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aura of Courage
entries: Starting at 10th level, you and friendly creatures within 10 feet of you can't be {@condition Frightened|phb} while you are conscious.
At 18th level, the range of this aura increases to 30 feet.

classFeature.name: Improved Divine Smite
entries: By 11th level, you are so suffused with righteous might that all your melee weapon strikes carry divine power with them. Whenever you hit a creature with a melee weapon, the creature takes an extra {@damage 1d8} radiant damage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Cleansing Touch
entries: Beginning at 14th level, you can use your action to end one spell on yourself or on one willing creature that you touch.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of once). You regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Sacred Oath.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aura improvements
entries: At 18th level, the range of your Aura of Protection increases to 30 feet.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sacred Oath feature
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Sacred Oath.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have significant experience studying, tracking, hunting, and even talking to a certain type of enemy commonly encountered in the wilds.

Choose a type of favored enemy: {@filter beasts|bestiary|type=beast}, {@filter fey|bestiary|type=fey}, {@filter humanoids|bestiary|type=humanoid}, {@filter monstrosities|bestiary|type=monstrosity}, {@filter plants|bestiary|type=plant}, or {@filter undead|bestiary|type=undead}. You gain a bonus to damage rolls with weapon attacks against creatures of the chosen type. Additionally, you have a bonus to Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to track or harvest from your favored enemies, as well as to Intelligence checks to recall information about them. This bonus scales with your level, as shown in the Favored Bonus column of the Ranger table.
Unless disguised, if a creature is your Favored Enemy, you know that it is and which creature type it is.

When you gain this feature, you also learn one language of your choice, typically one spoken by your favored enemy or creatures associated with it. However, you are free to pick any language you wish to learn.

You choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language, at 6th, 10th, 14th, and 20th level as shown in the Favored Enemy column of the Ranger table. As you gain levels, your choices should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures.

classFeature.name: Natural Explorer
entries: You are a master of navigating the natural world, and you react with swift and decisive action when attacked. This grants you the following benefits:

items: You ignore {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.
You have advantage on initiative rolls.
On your first turn during combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that have not yet acted.

entries: In addition, you are skilled at navigating the wilderness. You gain the following benefits when traveling for an hour or more:

items: Difficult terrain doesn't slow your group's travel.
Your group can't become lost except by magical means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as foraging, navigating, or tracking), you remain alert to danger.
If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
While tracking other creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: At 2nd level, you adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can't take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By the time you reach 2nd level, you have learned to use the magical essence of nature to cast spells, much as a druid does. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter ranger spell list|spells|class=ranger (THICC)}.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter ranger spells|spells|class=ranger (THICC)} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell animal friendship} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell animal friendship} using either slot.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter ranger spells|spells|class=ranger (THICC)}. To cast one of your {@filter ranger spells|spells|class=ranger (THICC)} of 1st level or higher, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of ranger spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the ranger spell list. When you do so, choose a number of ranger spells equal to your Wisdom modifier + half your ranger level, rounded down (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you are a 5th-level ranger, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With a Wisdom of 14, your list of prepared spells can include four spells of 1st or 2nd-level, in any combination. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell animal friendship}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or a 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of ranger spells requires time spent in prayer and meditation: ten minutes at the beginning of the day after a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your ranger spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a ranger spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item druidic focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your ranger spells. A {@item druidic focus|phb} might be a sprig of mistletoe or holly, a wand or rod made of yew or another special wood, a staff drawn whole from a living tree, or an object incorporating feathers, fur, bones, and teeth from sacred animals.

classFeature.name: Primeval Awareness
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, your mastery of ranger lore allows you to establish a powerful link to beasts and to the land around you.

While tracking a creature, you are able to gleam more information than most would find utilizing your surroundings. By spending 1 uninterrupted minute in concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell), you may determine extra information about the events that these tracks were formed in. You learn the speed they were traveling, an approximate number of how many there were, and what types of creatures were with them. If you are tracking one of your favored enemies, you also determine any notable differences in regular behavior (i.e. a panicked mood, infighting, etc.)

classFeature.name: Primeval Communication
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, your mastery of ranger lore allows you to establish a powerful link to beasts and to the land around you.

You have an innate ability to communicate with beasts, and they recognize you as a kindred spirit. Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas to a beast as an action, and can read its basic mood and intent. You learn its emotional state, whether it is affected by magic of any sort, its short-term needs (such as food or safety), and actions you can take (if any) to persuade it to not attack.
You cannot use this ability against a creature that you have attacked within the past 10 minutes.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave
entries: At 3rd level, you choose to emulate the ideals and training of a ranger conclave from the list of available conclaves. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 5th, 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Martial Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level ranger {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}

Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can replace a fighting style you know with another fighting style available to rangers. This replacement represents a shift of focus in your martial practice.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave feature
entries: At 5th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Greater Favored Enemy
entries: At 6th level, you are ready to hunt even deadlier game. Choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language. Your choice should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures. The types of favored enemies you can select increases to allow the following options in addition to the previous ones: {@filter aberrations|bestiary|type=aberration}, {@filter celestials|bestiary|type=celestial}, {@filter constructs|bestiary|type=construct}, {@filter dragons|bestiary|type=dragon}, {@filter elementals|bestiary|type=elemental}, {@filter fiends|bestiary|type=fiend}, or {@filter giants|bestiary|type=giant}.
Additionally, you gain expertise in two skills or tools of your choice related to your favored enemies.

classFeature.name: Roving
entries: At 6th level, you become adept in keeping up with your prey. Your walking speed increases by 5, and you gain a climbing speed and a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Superior Favored Enemy
entries: At 10th level, you know how to hide your presence while on the hunt. Choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language. Your choice should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures.

Additionally, you gain a bonus to stealth checks made to hide from your favored enemy equal to your favored bonus, and any hit on a favored enemy that has not yet acted during combat takes twice the damage they normally would from your Favored Bonus.

classFeature.name: Land's Stride
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action on your turn. You can also pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed by them and without taking damage from them if they have thorns, spines, or a similar hazard.
In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against plants that are magically created or manipulated to impede movement, such as those created by the {@spell entangle} spell.

classFeature.name: Hide in Plain Sight
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can spend 1 minute creating camouflage for yourself. You must have access to fresh mud, dirt, plants, soot, and other naturally occurring materials with which to create your camouflage.

Once you are camouflaged in this way, you can try to hide by pressing yourself up against a solid surface, such as a tree or wall, that is at least as tall and wide as you are. You gain a +10 bonus to Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks as long as you remain there without moving or taking actions. You lose this benefit if you take an action or a reaction, move, or fall {@condition Prone|phb}, either voluntarily or because of some external effect. Once you lose this benefit, you must camouflage yourself again to regain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave feature
entries: At 11th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Supreme Favored Enemy
entries: At 14th level, you know how to resist the disadvantages that come with hunting your prey. Choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language. Your choice should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures.

Additionally, you gain a bonus to all saving throws against any magical or mundane effect that your favored enemies force you to make equal to your Favored Bonus. This can include any spells cast, traps set, lair actions taken or any other feature used by your favored enemies.

classFeature.name: Vanish
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on your turn. Also, you can't be tracked by nonmagical means, unless you choose to leave a trail.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Feral Senses
entries: At 18th level, you gain preternatural senses that help you fight creatures you can't see. When you attack a creature you can't see, your inability to see it doesn't impose disadvantage on your attack rolls against it. You are also aware of the location of any {@condition Invisible|phb} creature within 30 feet of you, provided that the creature isn't hidden from you and you aren't {@condition blinded|phb} or {@condition Deafened|phb}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ultimate Favored Enemy
entries: At 20th level, you know how to counter the attacks made by your prey. Choose one additional favored enemy, as well as an associated language. Your choice should reflect the types of monsters you have encountered on your adventures.

Additionally, as a reaction to any attack roll made against you by a favored enemy, you can choose to gain a bonus to your AC against the triggering attack equal to your Favored Bonus. If you successfully block the attack, counter the enemy's attack, knocking them {@condition Wide Open}, giving them -1 to their AC until the end of their next turn.

classFeature.name: Tireless
entries: At 20th level, your body has gotten so adjusted to keeping up with prey that it is what you live for, allowing you to thrive in the hunt. As an action, you can give yourself a number of temporary hit points equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1 temporary hit point). You can use this action a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

In addition, whenever you finish a short rest, your exhaustion level, if any, is decreased by 1. This can not be used to remove Bestir Exhaustion, nor can it remove exhaustion gained from lingering injuries or diseases.

classFeature.name: Foe Slayer
entries: At 20th level, you become an unparalleled hunter. Once on each of your turns, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the attack roll or the damage roll of an attack you make. You can choose to use this feature before or after the roll, but before any effects of the roll are applied.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with {@item thieves' tools|phb}. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Sneak Attack
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe's distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra {@damage 1d6} damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.
You don't need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn't {@condition Incapacitated|phb}, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.
The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.

Additionally, on any attack in which Sneak Attack would apply, you may roll a {@dice d20} before making the attack. If the result is a 20, as long as your attack roll is not a 1, the attack is a critical hit. Otherwise, the attack happens as it normally would. The threshold for this extra crit increases at 6th level to 19, and again at 14th level to 18.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: During your rogue training you learned thieves' cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves' cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves' guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} action.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype
entries: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities from the list of available archetypes. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Steady Aim
entries: {@i 3rd-level rogue {@variantrule optional class features|THICC|optional feature}}

As a bonus action, you give yourself advantage on your next attack roll on the current turn. You can use this bonus action only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you use the bonus action, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain the benefit of Expertise.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or an {@spell ice storm} spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: By 15th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Nimbleness
entries: By 11th level, you have trained your body to be able to get where you need to in order to have the edge on your opponents. Pick 2 of the following options:

items: You ignore difficult terrain.
Your walking speed increases by 10 ft.
You gain a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.
You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.
You move at full speed while prone and getting up from being prone now only requires 5 feet of movement.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 14th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with {@item thieves' tools|phb}) to gain the benefit of Expertise.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Roguish Archetype feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Archetype.

classFeature.name: Elusive
entries: Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren't {@condition Incapacitated|phb}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the {@dice d20} roll as a 20.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin
entries: Choose a sorcerous origin, which describes the source of your innate magical power, from the list of available origins.
Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: An event in your past, or in the life of a parent or ancestor, left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with arcane magic. This font of magic, whatever its origin, fuels your spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|class=sorcerer (THICC)}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=Sorcerer (THICC)}. You learn an additional sorcerer cantrip of your choice at 4th level and another at 10th level.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Sorcerer table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter sorcerer spells|spells|class=sorcerer (THICC)} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these sorcerer spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell burning hands} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell burning hands} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the sorcerer spell list.

You learn an additional sorcerer spell of your choice at each level except 12th, 14th, 16th, 18th, 19th, and 20th. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the sorcerer spells you know and replace it with another spell from the sorcerer spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your sorcerer spells, since the power of your magic relies on your ability to project your will into the world. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. Innate Spellcasting may be performed using Charisma. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a sorcerer spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your sorcerer spells.

classFeature.name: Flexible Casting
entries: You can use your sorcery points to gain additional spell slots, or sacrifice spell slots to gain additional sorcery points. You learn other ways to use your sorcery points as you reach higher levels.

entries.name: Creating Spell Slots
entries: You can transform unexpended sorcery points into one spell slot as a bonus action on your turn. The created spell slots vanish at the end of a long rest. The Creating Spell Slots table shows the cost of creating a spell slot of a given level. You can create spell slots no higher in level than 5th.

entries.name: Converting a Spell Slot to Sorcery Points
entries: As a bonus action on your turn, you can expend one spell slot and gain a number of sorcery points equal to the slot's level.

classFeature.name: Font of Magic
entries: At 2nd level, you tap into a deep wellspring of magic within yourself. This wellspring is represented by sorcery points, which allow you to create a variety of magical effects.

classFeature.name: Sorcery Points
entries: You have 2 sorcery points, and you gain one additional point every time you level up, to a maximum of 20 at level 20. You can never have more sorcery points than shown on the table for your level. You regain all spent sorcery points when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 3rd level, you gain the ability to twist your spells to suit your needs. You gain two of the following Metamagic options of your choice. You gain another one at 10th and 17th level.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted.

classFeature.name: Metamagic Options
entries: {@i 3rd-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|THICC|optional feature}}
When you choose Metamagic options, you have access to the following additional options.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|THICC|optional feature}}
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, representing the magic within you flowing in new ways:

items: Replace one of the options you chose for the Metamagic feature with a different {@filter Metamagic option|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=MM} available to you.
Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|level=0|class=sorcerer (THICC)}.

classFeature.name: Magical Guidance
entries: {@i 5th-level sorcerer {@variantrule optional class features|THICC|optional feature}}

You can tap into your inner wellspring of magic to try to conjure success from failure. When you make an ability check that fails, you can spend 1 sorcery point to reroll the {@dice d20}, and you must use the new roll, potentially turning the failure into a success.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 10th level, you learn an additional metamagic option.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Metamagic
entries: At 17th level, you learn an additional metamagic option.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Origin feature
entries: At 18th level, you gain a feature granted by your Sorcerous Origin.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Sorcerous Restoration
entries: At 20th level, you regain 4 expended sorcery points whenever you finish a short rest.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron
entries: At 1st level, you have struck a bargain with an otherworldly being chosen from the list of available patrons. Your choice grants you features at 1st level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Pact Magic
entries: Your arcane research and the magic bestowed on you by your patron have given you facility with spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|class=Warlock (THICC)}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|level=0|class=Warlock (THICC)}. You learn additional warlock cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Warlock table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Warlock table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter warlock spells|spells|class=Warlock (THICC)} of 1st through 5th level. The table also shows what the level of those slots is; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your warlock spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest.
For example, when you are 5th level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell {@spell witch bolt}, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: At 1st level, you know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|level=1|class=Warlock (THICC)}

The Spells Known column of the Warlock table shows when you learn more warlock spells of your choice of 1st level and higher. A spell you choose must be of a level no higher than what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level. When you reach 6th level, for example, you learn a new warlock spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the warlock spells you know and replace it with another spell from the warlock spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your warlock spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a warlock spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a warlock spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and the spell is known.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your warlock spells.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: In your study of occult lore, you have unearthed eldritch invocations, fragments of forbidden knowledge that imbue you with an abiding magical ability.

At 2nd level, you gain two eldritch invocations of your choice. A list of the available options can be found on the {@filter Optional Features|optionalfeatures|Feature Type=EI} page. When you gain certain warlock levels, you gain additional invocations of your choice, as shown in the Invocations Known column of the Warlock table.
Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the invocations you know and replace it with another invocation that you could learn at that level.

If an eldritch invocation has prerequisites, you must meet them to learn it. You can learn the invocation at the same time that you meet its prerequisites. A level prerequisite refers to your level in this class.

classFeature.name: Pact Boon
entries: At 3rd level, your otherworldly patron bestows a gift upon you for your loyal service. You gain one of the following features of your choice.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Versatility
entries: {@i 4th-level warlock {@variantrule optional class features|tce|optional feature}}
Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, representing a change of focus in your occult studies:

items: Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Pact Magic feature with another cantrip from the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|level=0|class=Warlock (THICC)}.
Replace the option you chose for the Pact Boon feature with one of that feature's other options.
If you're 12th level or higher, replace one spell from your Mystic Arcanum feature with another warlock spell of the same level.

entries: If this change makes you ineligible for any of your Eldritch Invocations, you must also replace them now, choosing invocations for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Otherworldly Patron.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Otherworldly Patron.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (6th level)
entries: At 11th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 6th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=6|class=Warlock (THICC)} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

At higher levels, you gain more warlock spells of your choice that can be cast in this way: one 7th-level spell at 13th level, one 8th-level spell at 15th level, and one 9th-level spell at 17th level. You regain all uses of your Mystic Arcanum when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (7th level)
entries: At 13th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 7th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=7|class=Warlock (THICC)} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Otherworldly Patron feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Otherworldly Patron.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (8th level)
entries: At 15th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 8th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=8|class=Warlock (THICC)} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Mystic Arcanum (9th level)
entries: At 17th level, your patron bestows upon you a magical secret called an arcanum. Choose one {@filter 9th-level spell from the warlock spell list|spells|level=9|class=Warlock (THICC)} as this arcanum.
You can cast your arcanum spell once without expending a spell slot. You must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Master
entries: At 20th level, you can draw on your inner reserve of mystical power while entreating your patron to regain expended spell slots. You can spend 1 minute entreating your patron for aid to regain all your expended spell slots from your Pact Magic feature. Once you regain spell slots with this feature, you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: The power of belief holds strength in the hearts and minds of mankind. For Witches, it is held just as closely by the universe itself. Utilizing the power of belief to affect The Weave is called Witchcraft, and it is what all witches utilize to turn superstition into reality.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the {@filter witch spell list|spells|level=0|class=Witch (THICC)}. You learn additional Witch cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Witch table.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know two 1st-level spells of your choice from the {@filter witch spell list|spells|level=1|class=Witch (THICC)}.

You learn an additional witch spell of your choice at each level except 10th, 12th, 14th, 16th, 18th, 19th, and 20th. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the witch spells you know and replace it with another spell from the witch spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your Witchcraft, since your magic draws upon your devotion and attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for Witchcraft you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a Witch spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and the spell is known.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use any {@item arcane focus|phb} or {@item druidic focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your Witchcraft.

classFeature.name: Superstition
entries: Starting at 1st level, choose from the list of Superstitions for your Witch to focus on.
Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 20th level.

classFeature.name: Mumbo Jumbo
entries: Everyone and their children know not to cross a Witch, for to do so is to bring destruction upon your name. It is its own superstition; and thus, as Witches are feared, so too are they powerful. In a single utterance of a foul word or phrase, they bring about malediction towards their enemies.

Starting at 1st level, you can use a bonus action to force an enemy within 60 feet of yourself to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, they are cursed with a bout of misfortune. Once over the course of the next 10 minutes, you can make them subtract a die whose number of faces is equal to twice your proficiency bonus from any ability check, attack roll, or saving throw they make. (i.e. a proficiency bonus of 2 is a {@dice d4}, 3 is a {@dice d6}, etc.)
You can use this feature a number of times per long rest equal to your Wisdom modifier.

classFeature.name: Hoodoo
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your knowledge of curses refines and you are able to curse objects in a Witchcraft known as Hoodoo. Objects cursed by you in this way are your Tokens.

entries.name: Hoodoo Known
entries: When you gain this feature, you know two Hoodoo of your choice from the {@filter Hoodoo Table|optionalfeatures|feature type=HO:W}. You learn additional Hoodoo at later levels in this class, as shown in the Hoodoo Known column of the Witch table.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the Hoodoo you know with another one from the list.

entries.name: Creating Tokens
entries: Over the course of an hour, as if concentrating on a spell, you may perform a ritual on an object within 5 feet of you, as defined by a given Hoodoo, in order to curse it into one of your Tokens. If a Token requires attunement when you make it, you may choose to do so immediately, otherwise the token is unattuned by you.

You can only have a finite number of Tokens active at any given time, as shown in the Tokens column of the Witch table. You can purge the curse off of any Token as long as you know the Hoodoo it is cursed with by using a purging ritual unique to said Hoodoo that takes an hour, as if concentrating on a spell. Tokens may be unattuned from by a casting of {@spell Remove Curse|COOMS} as if the Token was cursed by a spell casted at a level equal to your spell save DC minus 10. If you attempt to create more than your maximum amount of Tokens, the oldest Token of yours is immediately purged, as your superstition is only so powerful. In addition, whenever you die, your Tokens continue to exist for a number of decades equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1 year). A Token may only be cursed by one Hoodoo at a time. Attempting to curse an already cursed Token results in the attempted curse failing to bind to the already-existing Token.
Attempting to make a Juju one of your Tokens is possible, though ill-advised.

classFeature.name: Witch Siphon
entries: Witches have a connection to the energy of the world through their superstitions, whether it be ki, the weave, or another method of phrasing the world's energy. This supernatural connection to energy allows them through the power of their belief to inflict the curses they perform, but it also allows them to absorb the energy of the world through their superstition.

At 2nd level, Witches have the ability to absorb the readily-accessible energy found in animated corpses, spirits, and automatons. When a Witch is within 30 feet of a construct or undead creature, the Witch may force them to make a Charisma saving throw against their spell save DC. On a failure, a binding that looks like warbling translucent wave connects you two as the Witch performs a series of incantations that draw out the energy of the creature. Immediately and for the next minute, as if concentrating on a spell, the Witch can use their action to deal 1d12 force damage to the creature. Keep track of how much damage this curse deals. While cursed by you, you know the location of the creature based on where the mirage-tendril that connects you both leads.

The curse breaks when the Witch loses {@status concentration|phb|concentration}, a minute passes, or the target dies. It also breaks if the Witch ends their turn with the target more than 30 feet away or not within line of sight. This includes if the target is on a different plane, such as the Ethereal Plane. When the curse breaks, take the total number of damage dealt by this curse and divide it by 20. You may recover a total number of combined spell slots equal to or less than that number. The level of the spell slots you recover can be no more than 5th-level.
You may use this feature once per long rest.

classFeature.name: Jujusense
entries: Rather than curses being inflicted upon a creature or object within reality, jujus are curses inflicted upon reality itself. Jujus are mystical artifacts governed by a series of complex rules, restrictions, or requirements. Only one copy of a juju exists across all dimensions. Any duplicates are always fated to become the other version at some other time. It is believed by many Witches that jujus can not be created, nor destroyed, merely transposed. For example, the destruction of a juju in one dimension may lead to its creation in another, with both acts being ordained and intertwined by fate.

At 3rd level, a Witch can tell whether an object is a juju within 30 feet at a glance, though you learn nothing about its properties. Their unusual nature screams out to you once your eyes lock with its cursed form. Jujus can take the form of any object. This could be a trinket they've been carrying around but aren't quite sure the purpose of whose nature is finally revealed to them, or it might be something they can stumble upon sometime later. Alternatively, through a series of complex events, a Witch may directly or indirectly lead to the creation of their juju. Though, there is no guarantee that a Witch will ever find or even own a juju due to their rarity.

If you are lucky enough, when a juju is in your possession, it is yours until it is either given or destroyed or you are killed. When lost or stolen, fate will always see to it that a juju is returned to its owner in one way or another. The utility of a juju may not be readily apparent, but it will always in some way serve a purpose to its owner, whether or not they realize it.

Because of the complex properties of a juju and its intertwining with fate, identifying them will only reveal simple, surface-level observations on the functionality of the juju, as truly comprehending every aspect of a juju is impossible for a mortal. True understanding of a juju comes with experience and the intuition of its owner.

classFeature.name: Wicked Harvest
entries: Witches are often feared because of their affinity with the misunderstood, for if it was understood, it wouldn't be supernatural. Another reason for the stigma they come with is their strange and off-putting curses, more than just Witchcraft in general.

At 3rd level, all Witches gain a new form of Witchcraft that they can do in order to harvest the lifeforce of those they defeat in battle, turning the dread the ritual brings about to further power their superstition. By arranging five bodies in a drawn star on the floor, with each head pointed at a tip of the star, a Witch can suck out the remaining lifeforce and any straggling bits of soul still remaining on a corpse, turning it into a dried-out husk as if they were mummified, disallowing them to be revivified.

Over the course of a short rest, as if concentrating, a Witch may designate five non-undead non-construct corpses that have not already been harvested whose heads are within five feet of each other and perform the curse on them. At the end of the short rest, if uninterrupted, you may recover a total number of combined spell slot levels equal to or less than half their total CR rounded down (the DM will tally this and tell you the number). The level of the spell slots you recover can be no more than 5th-level.
You may use this feature once per long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Witchcraft Versatility
entries: Whenever you reach a level in this class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can do one of the following, exchanging the curses and rituals you know for others as fate demands:
Replace one cantrip you learned from this class's Spellcasting feature with another cantrip from the {@filter Witch spell list|spells|level=0|class=Witch (THICC)}.

classFeature.name: Voodoo
entries: Starting at 5th level, your familiarity with curses has developed to allow you to place permanent curses on living creatures in a Witchcraft known as Voodoo. Cursing a creature in this way is called Jinxing.

entries.name: Voodoo Known
entries: When you gain this feature, you know three Voodoo of your choice from the {@filter Voodoo Table|optionalfeatures|feature type=VO:W}. You learn additional Voodoo at later levels in this class, as shown in the Voodoo Known column of the Witch table.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the Voodoo you know with another one from the list.

entries.name: Jinxing
entries: Over the course of an hour, as if concentrating on a spell, you may perform a ritual on a creature within 30 feet. Should they move too far from the ritual spot, the curse fails. At the end of the hour, the creature must make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a success, the creature is immune to any further jinx attempts by you until midnight. On a failure, they are Jinxed with the given Voodoo whose ritual was performed.

You can only have a finite number of Jinxes active at any given time, as shown in the Jinxes column of the Witch table. You can purge the curse of any Jinx as long as you know the Voodoo it is cursed with by using a purging ritual unique to said Voodoo that takes an hour, as if concentrating on a spell. Jinxes may also be purged by a casting of {@spell Remove Curse|COOMS} as if the Jinx was a curse casted at a level equal to your spell save DC minus 10. If you attempt to create more than your maximum amount of Jinxes, the oldest Jinx of yours ceases, as you can only affect the lives of so many with your superstition. In addition, whenever you die, your Jinxes continue to exist for a number of years equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1 year). A creature may be Jinxed by an infinite number of Voodoo at any given time.

classFeature.name: Spiritual Siphon
entries: Your familiarity with curses and the energy of the world has grown to be able to siphon away the magic of odd creatures, like those with a spirit but no body. Your siphon now assists you in purging those that might be considered a curse on the prime material plane.

At 5th level, your Witch Siphon now has the ability to affect aberrations, celestials, elementals, fey, fiends, and oozes as well. Your siphon now breaks if you are more than 90 feet from an enemy when your turn ends, and you now divide the total damage dealt by the siphon by 10 instead of 20 in order to determine how many spell slots you may recover. On top of this, your siphon binds the soul of the creature to the plane until they are dead. A creature cursed by your siphon no longer has the ability to shift planes.

classFeature.name: Superstition Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your superstition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Wiccan Transposition
entries: By 10th level, through your attunement to the energy of the world and its creatures, your body has become a conduit for magic. As a reaction, you are able to transfer a spell slot between creatures that touch you (including yourself). The level of the spell slot being transferred must not exceed your proficiency bonus. The creature sending the spell slot must have it and the creature receiving the spell slot must have room for it.
You may use this feature a number of times per long rest equal to your Wisdom modifier.
In addition, other creatures can join you in your Wicked Harvest as your acolytes, and when the ritual is successfully completed, you may distribute the slot levels amongst them as well as yourself.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Superstition Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your superstition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Cursed Magicks
entries: At 18th level, your understanding of your curses has peaked. Your siphon and harvest are both augmented to steal spell slots away from casters.

entries.name: Magick Siphon
entries: You are able to use Witch Siphon on any creature. When you siphon a creature that can cast spells, every time you deal damage with the Witch Siphon, you take their lowest spell slot that they have available. If you have no room to recover it, the spell slot dissipates into the atmosphere and is lost. There is no restriction on maximum spell slot level to be recovered from this feature.

entries.name: Magick Harvest
entries: You are able to reap the remnants of magic from any slain casters. Upon a successful Wicked Harvest, the remaining spell slots that weren't cast by the corpses are appended to the amount of spell slots you would have otherwise recovered. There is no restriction on maximum spell slot level to be recovered from this feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Superstition Feature
entries: At 20th level, you gain a feature granted by your superstition.

classFeature.name: Arcane Recovery
entries: You have learned to regain some of your magical energy by studying your spellbook. Once per day, when you finish a short rest, in which you spend the hour studying your spellbook as if concentrating on a spell, you can choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your wizard level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th level or higher.
For example, if you're a 4th-level wizard, you can recover up to two levels worth of spell slots.
You can recover either a 2nd-level spell slot or two 1st-level spell slots.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: As a student of arcane magic, you have a spellbook containing spells that show the first glimmerings of your true power. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and {@book chapter 11|PHB|11} for the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|class=wizard (THICC)}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know three cantrips of your choice from the {@filter wizard spell list|spells|level=0|class=Wizard (THICC)}. You learn additional wizard cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Wizard table.

entries.name: Spellbook
entries: At 1st level, you have a spellbook containing six 1st-level {@filter wizard spells|spells|class=wizard (THICC)} of your choice. Your spellbook is the repository of the wizard spells you know, except your cantrips, which are fixed in your mind.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Wizard table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your wizard spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of wizard spells that are available for you to cast. To do so, choose a number of wizard spells from your spellbook equal to your Intelligence modifier + your wizard level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you're a 3rd-level wizard, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination, chosen from your spellbook. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell magic missile}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or a 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of wizard spells requires time spent studying your spellbook and memorizing the incantations and gestures you must make to cast the spell: ten minutes at the beginning of the day after a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your wizard spells, since you learn your wizard spells through dedicated study and memorization. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a wizard spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a wizard spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell in your spellbook. You don't need to have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an {@item arcane focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your wizard spells.

entries.name: Learning Spells of 1st Level and Higher
entries: Each time you gain a wizard level, you can add two wizard spells of your choice to your spellbook. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots, as shown on the Wizard table. On your adventures, you might find other spells that you can add to your spellbook (see "Your Spellbook").

entries.name: Your Spellbook
entries: The spells that you add to your spellbook as you gain levels reflect the arcane research you conduct on your own, as well as intellectual breakthroughs you have had about the nature of the multiverse. You might find other spells during your adventures. You could discover a spell recorded on a scroll in an evil wizard's chest, for example, or in a dusty tome in an ancient library.
A spellbook doesn't contain the cantrips you learn from gaining levels in this or any other class.

entries.name: Copying a Spell into the Book
entries: When you find a wizard spell of 1st level or higher, you can add it to your spellbook if it is of a spell level you can prepare and if you can spare the time to decipher and copy it.

Copying a spell into your spellbook involves reproducing the basic form of the spell, then deciphering the unique system of notation used by the wizard who wrote it. You must practice the spell until you understand the sounds or gestures required, then transcribe it into your spellbook using your own notation.

For each level of the spell, the process takes 2 hours and costs two half-uses of a kraken inkwell (aka 1 usage of kraken ink). The cost represents material components you expend as you experiment with the spell to master it, as well as the fine inks you need to record it. Once you have spent this time and money, you can prepare the spell just like your other spells.

entries.name: Copying from a Spell Scroll
entries: A wizard spell on a spell scroll can be copied just as spells in spellbooks can be copied. When you copy a spell from a spell scroll, you must succeed on an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check with a DC equal to 10 + the spell's level. If the check succeeds, the spell is successfully copied. Whether the check succeeds or fails, the spell scroll is destroyed.

entries.name: Copying outside of your Spell List
entries: If you wish to input either a cantrip or a spell not in your class' spell list into your spellbook, you must possess either a spellbook that contains said cantrip or outside spell already present within its texts, or you must succeed on copying 5 scrolls of that cantrip/spell consecutively as you attempt to either boil it down to its bare essence so that you can easily remember it for cantrips or decipher the foreign magic into arcane casting for spells not in the wizard spell list. These cannot be recovered from memory into a new spellbook if you lose your old one.

entries.name: Replacing the Book
entries: You can copy a spell from your own spellbook into another book—for example, if you want to make a backup copy of your spellbook. This is just like copying a new spell into your spellbook, but faster and easier, since you understand your own notation and already know how to cast the spell. You need to spend only 1 hour and 1 half-use of a kraken inkwell for every 2 levels of the copied spell.

If you lose your spellbook, you can use the same procedure to transcribe the spells that you have prepared into a new spellbook. Filling out the remainder of your spellbook requires you to find new spells to do so, as normal. For this reason, many wizards keep backup spellbooks in a safe place.

entries.name: The Book's Appearance
entries: Your spellbook is a unique compilation of spells, with its own decorative flourishes and margin notes. It might be a plain, functional leather volume that you received as a gift from your master, a finely bound gilt-edged tome you found in an ancient library, or even a loose collection of notes scrounged together after you lost your previous spellbook in a mishap.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition
entries: When you reach 2nd level, you choose an arcane tradition from the list of available traditions, shaping your practice of magic. Your choice grants you features at 2nd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Cantrip Formulas
entries: {@i 3rd-level wizard {@variantrule optional class features|THICC|optional feature}}

You have scribed a set of arcane formulas in your spellbook that you can use to formulate a cantrip in your mind. Whenever you finish a long rest and consult those formulas in your spellbook, you can replace one wizard cantrip you know with another cantrip from the wizard spell list.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Arcane Tradition feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Arcane Tradition.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Spell Mastery
entries: At 18th level, you have achieved such mastery over certain spells that you can cast them at will. Choose a 1st-level wizard spell and a 2nd-level wizard spell that are in your spellbook. You can cast those spells at their lowest level without expending a spell slot when you have them prepared. If you want to cast either spell at a higher level, you must expend a spell slot as normal.
By spending 8 hours in study, you can exchange one or both of the spells you chose for different spells of the same levels.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Signature Spells
entries: When you reach 20th level, you gain mastery over two powerful spells and can cast them with little effort. Choose two 3rd-level wizard spells in your spellbook as your signature spells. You always have these spells prepared, they don't count against the number of spells you have prepared, and you can cast each of them once at 3rd level without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
