Until the start of your next turn, any creature that enters within 10 feet of you for the first time in a turn or starts its turn there takes cold damage equal to your warlock level + your Charisma modifier, and if a creature ends its turn within 10 feet of you, it takes radiant damage equal to your warlock level + your Charisma modifier.
You may use this feature a number of times per short or long rest equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Refuge
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to step into an astral refuge, if only momentarily. As an action, you disappear from the world for a brief moment and enter the Astral Plane, taking advantage of its timeless nature. While in your astral refuge, you can take two actions and two bonus actions that cannot affect any creature other than you. After using those two actions, you return to the space you occupied and your turn ends.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Sequestration
entries: Starting at 10th level, you gain the ability to sequester yourself and your allies on the Astral Plane.

By performing a special ritual over the course of one minute, you shift yourself and up to ten willing creatures you can see to the Astral Plane. You and those creatures gain the benefits of a short rest while sequestered on the Astral Plane. You then return to the spaces you all occupied when you used this ability, with no time having passed in the world.
During this short rest, you and the creatures you sequester can make use of any options available during a rest that affect only you and the creatures you sequester.
Once you use this ability, you cannot use it again until you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Astral Being
entries: At 14th level, you no longer need to eat, drink, or breathe, and you gain resistance to cold damage and radiant damage. When you use your Shielding Aurora, the resistance you gained from this feature turns to immunity.

subclassFeature.name: Idolatry
entries: Idolaters worship an object as though it were a god. To many, it is just a strange fixation, but to a very few, like any Witch out there, you can ask and they will tell you it is no ordinary object. Idolaters worship a juju, a curse upon reality that may or may not have its own set of morals and goals that differ far from that of any mortal being, though seem to align well with the idolater that they have chosen.

When you choose this subclass, you learn the {@spell Thaumaturgy|COOMS} cantrip. In addition, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Idolatry Superstition Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a Witch spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Witch spells you know.

entries.caption: Idolatry Superstition Spells
rows: {@spell Aura of Vitality|phb}, {@spell Beacon of Hope|phb}
{@spell Aura of Life|phb}, {@spell Aura of Purity|phb}

entries.name: Juju Idol
entries: At 1st level, or since a time in your past, you had an encounter that put you in the possession of or led to the creation of your idol. Your idol is respected, or feared, by you as a god that is bound to you by fate. It might have its own set of goals that more often than not would align with yours in a grand cosmic scheme. That is, of course, a part of the superstition. For the most part, no idols have the ability to communicate or articulate their desires. Idolaters simply "feel" the desire of their idol; it is their gut instinct.

You can discuss with your DM how you obtained your idol or how it came to be, though its goals may remain mysterious to you. As it is a juju, it can't be stolen from you, as it will always end up back in your possession unless you are killed or you give it away, not that you would want to do so. In fact, any creature who knowingly and willingly touches your idol other than yourself places a curse upon themselves for a malice to fall upon them in the next 24 hours. It can be something as simple as tripping at an inopportune time to momentarily halt the group they are traveling with or something as career destroying as defecating themselves in front of the royal court. The curse must always be something that furthers the goals of the juju at the expense of the cursed. It acts as your spellcasting focus for your Witch spells, and you gain proficiency with a set of tools related to maintaining your idol.

subclassFeature.name: Lamb Slaughter
entries: At 6th level, you have learned how to empower your Juju to reach your goals together. When you perform your Wicked Harvest, you may choose to designate CR to your idol to empower it. With 1 CR designated to your idol, it becomes a +1 magical focus. With 10 CR, it becomes +2. With 100 CR, it becomes a +3 magical focus, and so on with this pattern continuing. This bonus lasts until a tenday passes or until you designate an amount of CR on a Wicked Harvest to meet or exceed the current magical bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Grand Prophecy
entries: As far as you've had the idol, you've always felt its desires as though they were your own, but at 14th level, and maybe even some time before, you can hear your idol speak to you as though you were its high priest, and it your god. You learn the {@spell Commune} spell and can cast it once per long rest for free, though you can also choose to use your spell slots to cast it as well. In addition, you may choose to focus on the cacophony of voices that surround your head when your juju is near to focus on its true desires. As an action, a number of times per long rest equal to your Wisdom modifier, you may hear a message from your idol. This message could be advice, directions, demands, or the like. Should your juju wish to speak, you will feel as though this is the case. Whether or not you listen is up to you.

subclassFeature.name: Judgemental Visage
entries: By 20th level, your idol has accrued enough power to take on the appearance of a god to any onlookers. When you cast your Witch Siphon while holding your idol, you can allow your idol to take possession of your siphon instead. Any creature that you designate within 60 feet of yourself that can see your idol must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the targets take {@damage 10d12} radiant damage and your siphon immediately ends, with all damage being tallied together for your siphon as usual. Any creature that failed the saving throw is also {@condition blinded|phb} for one minute, having to remake the save at the end of their turns to be unblinded. Any creature that succeeds this saving throw takes half damage and is not {@condition blinded|phb}. Any creature killed by this feature is turned into a charred skeleton, as their flesh, muscles, eyes, etc. melt away.

subclassFeature.name: Mysticism
entries: Mystics are often mistrusted or considered quacks, more than any other Witch. People call what they do a scam, and most people only go to them for fun. Though to them, fate can be read like a book, skipping to a future page and skimming it to tell any clients what might happen. From palm readings, tea leaves, crystal balls, and special cards, they are nothing if not showmen when they do tell the future.

When you choose this subclass, you gain proficiency with {@item Playing Card Set|phb|Playing Cards Sets} and learn the {@spell Prestidigitation|COOMS} cantrip. In addition, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Mysticism Superstition Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a Witch spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Witch spells you know.

entries.name: Fateful Sortilege
entries: Fate isn't simply just negativity; the balance of fate has positivity as well. Thus, when you speak of the future, you are able to state it, both good and bad. At 1st level, you are able to use your Mumbo Jumbo on allies. When you do so, they can choose to fail the saving throw. When used on allies in this way, they can add the die to one of their next attack rolls, ability checks, or saving throws instead of subtracting it like a target of Mumbo Jumbo normally would.

subclassFeature.name: Fortune Telling
entries: At 6th level, you can read the fate of one willing creature in front of you. By using tea leaves, special playing cards, or even the palms of the creature's hand, you are able to divine fate. You spend 10 minutes in {@status concentration|phb|concentration} while near the creature telling their fortune with enough showmanship to call what you do nothing short of a spectacle. Your reading lasts until they take a long rest, and you are able to read people's fortunes a number of times per long rest equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). A creature cannot have its fortune read more than once per long rest. Roll on the Fortune Telling table below to see the effect of your reading.

rows.name: Misfortune
items: Sometime today, they will suffer a great loss. Warn them that their life is in danger, and they need to keep safe, lest they lose it all.

rows.name: Disastrous
items: Subtract {@dice 1d4-1} from their Dexterity score as you tell them how a reality-shifting malice will fall upon them.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Cursed
items: Subtract {@dice 1d4-1} from their Charisma score as you tell them how they will suffer a curse if they slight the wrong person today.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Helpless
items: Subtract {@dice 1d4-1} from their Strength score as you tell them how they will be pushed around by the waves of fate today.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Fragile
items: Subtract {@dice 1d4-1} from their Constitution score as you tell them how they will succumb to an illness if they are not careful today.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Ignorant
items: Subtract {@dice 1d4-1} from their Wisdom score as you tell them how they will miss an opportunity if they don't keep their eyes open to it.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Forgotten
items: Subtract {@dice 1d4-1} from their Intelligence score as you tell them how they must search their memory for something important they forgot a long time ago.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Omen
items: Roll on the Mystic Reading table as you offer them a strange warning.

rows.name: Unclear
items: The fortune is difficult to grasp. Roll this table twice as you state that their future holds an incredible amount of outcomes today.

rows.name: Sign
items: Roll on the Mystic Reading table as you offer them strange advice.

rows.name: Tough
items: Add {@dice 1d4-1} to their Constitution score as you tell them how they will withstand a great hardship today but come out stronger because of it.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Popular
items: Add {@dice 1d4-1} to their Charisma score as you tell them how they will meet a new ally today.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Strong
items: Add {@dice 1d4-1} to their Strength score as you tell them how they will have a great feat of strength happen today.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Discovery
items: Add {@dice 1d4-1} to their Intelligence score as you tell them how they will make a great discovery today.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Special
items: Add {@dice 1d4-1} to their Wisdom score as you tell them how they will notice something that others will not. This is the key to their success.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Lucky
items: Add {@dice 1d4-1} to their Dexterity score as you tell them how they will dodge a misfortune today with their luck.
Should you roll a 1 on the {@dice d4}, ignore this and instead roll on the Mystic Reading table.

rows.name: Fortune
items: Today is rich with potential for them. Tell them to enjoy the day to the fullest, as the odds are on their side.

entries.caption: Mystic Reading Table
rows: Beware the blinding red light. If you see this light, you must flee. It will only bring you death!
You will find the answer to a long, mysterious riddle in your family bloodline buried between two oak trees, west of the village you grew up in.
A path of death lies in your wake.
Greed is a poor man's compass, and I see gold and riches in your future.
A single wolf is slaughtered by many enemies that surround it. Let this be a warning sign of danger that is preventable by the pack.
The truth will come from a child's toy. The lie will come from a weapon.
You must drink of the poison well and eat of the spoiled pantry.
Follow the flight of birds, never in winter, always returning.
A song contains a wish. Only the name will answer.
The mother has disguised herself. Her babe is lost and will not return. She will nurse no other.
The gears turn long after the machine has been broken. He who built it cannot mend it. He who holds it cannot carry it. He who finds it cannot speak it.
Gaze through the cracked window, and only then will you see clearly.
Beware the men with gills. Speak not to the sea or the southern wind.
Beware the snake's venom, not its bite.
Travel five days with the silver star at your heels, then cross the raging river. There you will come to realize your true self.
The light will be in the shadowest darkness.
Not all the frogs are in the pond, beware of them.
One for the fire, two for the clouds, and three for the knights.
Don't trust the song of the birds.
Cloak in the water. The man is crying. Let the leaf falls and everything will be fine.
For one wish to make, it'll be more wish to crumble.
In the high plain there's a dark moon. Don't follow the light.
When the dawn will come at the birthday of the mother, rats and snakes will devour all hopes.
Near the mountains, there is a grey falcon. Look at the eyes, and you'll die. Look at the tail, and you'll be rich.
Don't move when the night song come, or you'll gain something you don't want, and lose something you wanted to keep.

Today was possibly the most important day of your life! Congrat.. oh... you missed it... tsk tsk tsk... What a shame... A do-over, then! Tomorrow you will wake up and it will be today. Make sure you return or that decree will stay. Okay, thanks, bye!
Do not trust your thoughts. They will hinder your victory.
A figment in blue will cross your path tomorrow. You will know it when you see the sign. You must turn around 4 times and speak the following words:
And through the drifts the snowy cliffs Did send a dismal sheen: Nor shapes of men nor beasts we ken The ice was all between.
If you believe in telekinesis, raise my hand. The fortune teller then proceeds to raise their hand.
When you are done, the spirit haunting will pass over you.
A dragon will give you a jewel. Beware the generous miser.
The path less traveled is paved in gold.
Find the woman who gives birds their song.
Beware, young mouse, for the lion is thorned.
The Moon Shines Brightest to Those in Her Favor.
Speak Not The Name Unspoken; They Listen, Always.
Beware, for the Great Gyre is Nigh; The Slouching Beast Will Soon Arrive!
Swords Shall Pierce Thine Heart; Pin Thy Love Lest It Be Lost.
Three Crones Shall Visit Thee and Thier Lights Shall Reveal the Truth of What Thou Doth Seek!
Keep a Candle Burning; Lest The Dark Take Even Your Fears Away.
Build Not Houses of White Stone.
Three Coins Must Ye Pay; Three Prices Dear, Secrets Thrice Revealed, 'ere The Light of Day.
Gold, Silver, Copper; Never in the Opposite Order!
Spill Forth a Dram for the Lost; Make Merry in the Name of Those Who Pay the Highest Price!
You Must Seek the Leaf that Grows Not On Any Tree!
Jump the Broom; Dance above the Blades!
Sphinx of Black Quartz, Judge Thy Vow.
Seek the Egg of Stone; Face the Dragon!
Your nights will grow colder still, to match the heat of growing fires.
Trust the twin with no siblings, but abhor the lone child.
The face of the one you seek is thus- a busker at dawn; a composer at noon; a patron at dusk; a maestro under the stars.
Your money, here, have it back. The fortune you've asked me to read, never shall I speak of it in this life or any hereafter.
A wilting lineage droops to shadowy lows. What the rotten fruit begets chokes out the tree of its birth.
Beware! Blessings from above may actually be curses from below!
A helping hand will come from an unlikely place. Trust it at your own peril.
When the leaves fall from the trees so too shall the stars fall from the sky.
The wisest men envy the grave.
The poison of the moon lies only once.
There be dragons in ye head. Make sure to feed them.
The treasure you are looking for is in the fruit.
Poorly-dresed skanks like you will die alone. Naked, and alone.
Never bring upon yourself the wrath of the chicken. You may think this a metaphor, but it is not. Their beaks are sharp like my toes.
Your hands will taste of orange in the near future.
That which you hold most dear will turn against you and lead you to ruin
Your actions have had unintended and unforeseeable consequences, and have placed into action the final piece of that which now approaches you. You are the harbinger of your own death
The thoughts you have had but not put into action are leading you down a path to your own undoing
The fall of slow rain upon the barren field will lead you to the house which shelters your destiny
Steel your heart for darkness ahead. Your betrayal has already happened though you do not yet know it.
Seek ye the good behind the bad and beware the bad behind the good.
Never lick a horse in the mouth, they bite.
A Fall is Coming; Winter Just Round the Bend; Enjoy Spring; Summer Shall Bring An End!
Let Not Cold Enter Your Heart, For Then Only Love Can Drive It Out!
The black sky will shield you from your enemies. Travel by night.
The rope with which you climb may also hang you if you are not careful.
You will be an old man/woman by the time your quest is complete.
Fools will take great heed of your words. Use this to your advantage.
A shrewd and very attractive fortune teller has put a curse on you. I will remove it for an additional sum.
Trust not the travelers numbering odd.
Take something old, give something new, doubt something red, trust something blue.
Left at the stream, at the face look right, crawl through the dark, and you will find the light!
Salt thy wounds, relish the sting, sweet is the knave, and bold is the king.
Thrice will call the raven, heed its warn lest the fourth cry your dirge.
Between silver and gold, choose evil's bane. Between fire and chill, the lady's kiss.
The shadow of the dragon is an omen, but coming of the wolf is the sign.
Begrudge not the thieving monkey, lest you take its place in the tiger's jaws.
Lay not your head in the barn animals' bed, for the headsman soon calls.
A copper for the maid, a silver to the beggar, and a gold for a lonely tune, may the vault of riches open to you.
Someone you remember, someone you forget, someone with a favor, another with a threat.
Poor fortune for ye, unless you confess your guilt to the willow tree.
Your luck is a shame until you trade with your mate who has one of the same.
A fortune most cold if you do as you're told.
Torch and candle, wax and wick, in the hall of fire, move right quick!
Look for the priestess, she will bring salvation.
An ancient empire will rise from the waves along with ancient secrets.
Only when the lovers are reunited can the curse be broken.
As the hermit emerges from hiding, darkness shall soon emerge as well.
Watch for a nobleman in red, for he is a devil in disguise.

subclassFeature.name: Forger of Fate
entries: At 14th level, you perceive fate as a stream of choices, a stream in which you can influence to alter the future. During your initial roll of a given Fortune Telling, you may reroll it and use either roll for your reading. Additionally, you are able to acquire your Mumbo Jumbo back on a short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Author of Destiny
entries: By 20th level, you dictate fate as if life was a story that you tell existence to write. When you use your Mumbo Jumbo on an enemy, the target automatically fails the saving throw.

In addition, you have cursed so many with your words of spite that your curse words are eternal. Once per long rest, as an action, you can attempt to cast a Voodoo immediately on someone within 60 feet of yourself as your words themselves can alter fate.

subclassFeature.name: Grand Prophecy
entries: As far as you've had the idol, you've always felt its desires as though they were your own, but at 14th level, and maybe even some time before, you can hear your idol speak to you as though you were its high priest, and it your god. You learn the {@spell Commune} spell and can cast it once per long rest for free, though you can also choose to use your spell slots to cast it as well. In addition, you may choose to focus on the cacophony of voices that surround your head when your juju is near to focus on its true desires. As an action, a number of times per long rest equal to your Wisdom modifier, you may hear a message from your idol. This message could be advice, directions, demands, or the like. Should your juju wish to speak, you will feel as though this is the case. Whether or not you listen is up to you.

subclassFeature.name: Judgemental Visage
entries: By 20th level, your idol has accrued enough power to take on the appearance of a god to any onlookers. When you cast your Witch Siphon while holding your idol, you can allow your idol to take possession of your siphon instead. Any creature that you designate within 60 feet of yourself that can see your idol must make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the targets take {@damage 10d12} radiant damage and your siphon immediately ends, with all damage being tallied together for your siphon as usual. Any creature that failed the saving throw is also {@condition blinded|phb} for one minute, having to remake the save at the end of their turns to be unblinded. Any creature that succeeds this saving throw takes half damage and is not {@condition blinded|phb}. Any creature killed by this feature is turned into a charred skeleton, as their flesh, muscles, eyes, etc. melt away.

subclassFeature.name: Occultism
entries: Feared for practicing dark rituals for long-forgotten deities or personal gain, these are by far the most feared type of Witch and they are what give all Witches a bad name. Occultists' rituals are their bread and butter, knowing some sort of odd diagram to draw in an animal's blood while chanting a nefarious incantation to do just about anything, such as cleaning their chamber that is now tainted with a pentagram of pig's blood.

When you choose this subclass, you gain proficiency with {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|OWL} and learn the {@spell Prestidigitation|COOMS} cantrip. In addition, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Occultism Superstition Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a Witch spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Witch spells you know.

entries.name: Ritualist
entries: Your mind is a well-spring for chantings, drawn-symbols, and the like. When you pick this superstition at 1st level, you are able to cast spells that have the ritual tag from the Witch spell list that you don't currently know. Spells affected by this feature must be of a level that you can cast. You can't cast the spells except as rituals, unless you've learned them by some other means.

subclassFeature.name: Blood Rituals
entries: At 6th level, you discover that your Wicked Harvest can empower more than just yourself. It's a special ritual that can empower other rituals, like your Voodoo.

When you perform your Wicked Harvest, you can choose to perform a Voodoo at the same time on someone within your Voodoo range. When you do so, you can choose to give the target of your Voodoo a penalty to their saving throw equal to an amount of CR you wish to discard from the total in your Wicked Harvest. Additionally, at later levels when you gain the ability for acolytes to join you in your harvest, each acolyte adds onto this penalty at a rate of 1 per acolyte.

Alternatively, you can use your Wicked Harvest to empower your rituals. When you perform your Wicked Harvest, you can choose to perform a ritual at the same time. When you do, you are able to distribute an amount of CR to your ritual to empower it to a spell level equal to twice the CR distributed. Additionally, at later levels when you gain the ability for acolytes to join you in your harvest, each acolyte adds onto the CR distributed at a rate of 1 per acolyte.

subclassFeature.name: Forgotten Practice
entries: By 14th level, your study of rituals has afforded you the knowledge not many others can say they possess. You learn that all spells can be ritual casted if you know the specific ritual for them. You are able to cast a non-ritual spell as a ritual once per day.

subclassFeature.name: Irons in the Fire
entries: At 14th level, you also have mastered the technique of scheming such that multitasking comes as second nature to you as your rituals. When you cast a ritual, you may choose to cast a second ritual at the same time. You can do this per long rest a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and this feature can combine with your Forgotten Practice to allow you to cast two non-ritual spells as a ritual together.

subclassFeature.name: Occult Siphon
entries: At 20th level, you have become an occult leader. As such, not only can you have acolytes during your Wicked Harvest, but also your Witch Siphon. When you cast your Witch Siphon on a target, any number of your allies within 30 feet of that target can use a reaction to mimic your gestures and chantings to join you in your siphon. When doing so, they are required to maintain {@status concentration|phb|concentration}, appropriate distance, and any other caveats required by the siphon. Thus, during their turns, they can spend their action to deal {@damage 1d12} force damage to the target, and if they do not, the siphon breaks for them. If the siphon breaks for any one of your acolytes, they can not join back into the siphon. If you for any reason break the siphon, for instance if you lost {@status concentration|phb|concentration} or were too far away from the target, then the siphon breaks for your acolytes as well. The damage your acolytes do is tallied with your damage for calculating how many spell slots you acquire at the end of your siphon. The results of the siphon can be distributed to any creatures that joined in on the siphon once it is finished, at your discretion.

subclassFeature.name: Psychic
entries: Psychics develop a sense about the world that is impossible to describe, though to them it feels all too real. Much like you can't describe what "Red" is to a person born without sight, psychics can experience the world in ways the average person couldn't comprehend. This sixth sense of theirs leads them to be able to know things a normal person couldn't, and most of them follow this indescribable feeling without hesitation just as anyone would trust their five senses to tell them about the world.

When you choose this subclass, you gain proficiency with Insight (or expertise if you already have proficiency) and learn the {@spell Prestidigitation|COOMS} cantrip. In addition, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Psychic Superstition Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a Witch spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Witch spells you know.

entries.caption: Psychic Superstition Spells
rows: {@spell Detect Evil and Good|phb}, {@spell Sense Emotion|COOMS}

entries.name: Pecuilar Intuition
entries: This is your sixth sense; how you perceive the world differently from others. At 1st level, you learn to listen to this sense as you would any other. While experiencing something (i.e. seeing an object, smelling a creature, etc.) you can use a bonus action to listen to your sixth sense. When you do so, roll a blind Insight check to gain an odd to important bit of information about the thing you are experiencing (depending on the results of the roll, as determined by your DM).
You can also use this feature to replace any Intelligence or Wisdom skill check with an Insight check. You can use this feature a number of times per short rest equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Shaman
entries: Every tribe needs a leader. Typically tribes are led by the toughest, oldest, or by those who can hear the words from those above. Shamans believe in a higher power, which can be a tribal pantheon (e.g., the orcish pantheon) or by turning nature itself into its own deity (the "sky god"). Whatever the case may be, shamans interpret everyday activities as messages from the higher power, be that positive or negative. For example, a shaman may interpret a bad harvest as being the result of their enraged higher power needing appeasement, or they may decide that their higher power is testing their tribe, etc. Whatever the case may be, they seek to lead their tribe to victory.

When you choose this subclass, you gain proficiency with cutlasses, falchions, khopeshes, kukri, mambele, scimitars, and war fans as well as nonmetal light armor, nonmetal light, and nonmetal medium shields, learning the {@spell Thaumaturgy|COOMS} cantrip on top of this. In addition, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Shaman Superstition Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a Witch spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Witch spells you know.

entries.name: Tribal Mask
entries: Starting at 1st level, you have a tribal mask carved of wood and possibly painted that offers protection. While you wear the tribal mask, your AC increases by 1 and you have a bonus to your Athletics and Intimidation equal to your Wisdom modifier. If your mask breaks, you can carve a new one over the course of a short rest using {@item Woodcarver's Tools|phb}.

subclassFeature.name: Chief's Chanting
entries: Sealing the fate of your enemy does not need to simply rely on their failures, but rather the success of your team. At 6th level, you gain the ability to use your Mumbo Jumbo on your allies. When you do so, they can choose to fail the saving throw. When used on allies in this way, instead of Mumbo Jumbo's normal effects, once over the course of the next 10 minutes, the given ally can roll the die to add it to a weapon attack or weapon damage roll they make.

In addition, you have learned how to sacrifice to appease your deity. During your Wicked Harvest, you may choose a number of bodies to designate as being sacrifices. Sacrifices are kept out of the total CR that you are absorbing as magic, and instead have their CR tallied separately. You are able to recover a number of expent Mumbo Jumbo uses equal to their total CR.

subclassFeature.name: Surge of the Skies
entries: At 14th level, you feel a strong connection to your higher power, allowing you to momentarily act as their avatar if you concentrate on the link between you and them. As an action, channel the wrath of your higher power and overflow with their might, causing your eyes to glow. You emit bright light out to 30 feet and dim light an additional 30 feet in the direction you are looking as if using a {@item Bullseye Lantern|phb}. Electricity surges through your body, and for the next 10 minutes, you gain the following benefits:

items: You are resistant to lightning, radiant, and thunder damage.

You have a flying speed of 30 ft. If you are still flying when the feature ends, you float gracefully downwards as if under the effects of the feather fall spell for 1 minute or until you land, whichever is first.

You can use your action to hurl two bolts of golden sunlight at your opponents. Make a ranged spell attack towards an enemy within 100 ft, or 300 at disadvantage. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d6} lightning and {@damage 2d6} radiant damage. You make this attack twice.
You can use your action to emit a line of lightning from yourself out to 60 ft. Any creature within this line must make a Dexterity Saving throw or take {@damage 4d8} lightning damage.

You can use your action to breathe the chill of winter in a 30-foot cone in front of you. Creatures in that cone must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 3d8} cold damage and have their speed halved until the end of their next turn.

You can use your action to emit a thunderous roar that can be heard 500-ft away. Any creature within a 30-ft radius of you must make a Strength saving throw or take {@damage 4d6} thunder damage and be knocked 20 feet away from you.

entries: While this feature is active, if you are outside, it rains in a 500-ft radius around you after {@dice 1d4} minutes. This feature ends early if you lose {@status concentration|phb|concentration}. You are able to use this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: God Conduit
entries: At 20th level, your body becomes a channel for the gods. You have resistance to lighting and radiant damage. On top of this, all weapon attacks you make become magical and deal an additional {@damage 2d6} lightning damage. All spells you cast that deal lightning damage deal an additional {@damage 2d6} radiant damage as your lightning is imbued with the energy of the sky. While your Surge of the Skies is active, you control what weather effect happens and you gain immunity to lightning and radiant damage, on top of resistance to thunder damage.

subclassFeature.name: Secrets of the Dead
entries: Starting at 6th level, your alignment with the world and the creatures in it increases, allowing you to sense more of the world. Whenever you use your Wicked Harvest, you also harvest random memories from the corpses; remnants that flavor the life essence you harvest like seasoning on a steak. They flash through your head during the ritual sporadically. You do not inherently know what memory came from who, though you can try to focus in on specific memories that might be left by one or more of them. When you do so, roll an insight check to learn specific information or experiences from them. The results of the roll are up to the discretion of the DM.

Either way, when you finish your Wicked Harvest, until you finish a long rest, you gain proficiency or expertise in one skill, tool, or language of your choice that one of the corpses had proficiency or expertise in.

subclassFeature.name: Echoes of the Past
entries: Remnants of memories don't just populate the corpses you harvest, they litter the world around us, something you become more than familiar with. At 14th level, you can concentrate on your place in the world to see a vision of something that once occurred at a location you are currently in. When you do so, you see the ghosts of what once was, and become somewhat detached from the world around you. The visions last for a number of minutes equal to your Wisdom score or until you are broken out of {@status concentration|phb|concentration}.
You can do this a number of times per long rest equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Empathic Cognizance
entries: At 20th level, your sixth sense has become so powerful that you are able to steal memories from the living. During your Witch Siphon, you experience the life of your target. Every time you deal damage with your siphon, you see a series of flashes from your target's memory. Roll an Insight check every time you deal damage to determine the relevance of the memory or bit of knowledge you experience.

If your siphon lasts a minute, you absorb their memories, learning everything about their life, goals, etc. If your target is still alive when you complete your siphon for the entire minute, you can modify their memories in any way you see fit, rewiring their mind to your wishes.

subclassFeature.name: Witchdoctor
entries: Witchdoctors are known by two names depending on who you ask, but most regard them as quacks. Often found peddling poultices made from whatever they happen to find mystical as cure-alls for ailments as snake-oil merchants, people regard Witchdoctors and their panacea to be nothing more than predatory and shady merchants preying upon suckers dumb enough to use their pseudo-alchemy as if it were real. Townies that have nobody else to turn to, no temple in their village for when their children are sick, will turn to their only option. They will look upon the shack atop the hill in their time of need, when all they can do is put their belief in the Witchdoctor. That's when a Witchdoctor turns from a quack to a miracle-worker.

When you choose this subclass, you gain proficiency with {@item Herbalism Kit|phb|Herbalism kits} and learn the {@spell Druidcraft|COOMS} cantrip. In addition, you learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Witchdoctor Superstition Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a Witch spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of Witch spells you know.

entries.name: Healing Poultice
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can spend ten minutes as if in {@status concentration} mixing together a litany of random ingredients you have stashed away to produce a healing poultice in an empty bottle out of seemingly nothing. You can do this a number of times per long rest equal to your proficiency bonus.

A healing poultice is a cream, oil, or other tonic that is applied to the areas of injury in order to promote healing in that area. A creature can spend a minute to apply the poultice to a creature's injury. When it does so, the injured creature regains hit points equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Wisdom modifier, and can choose to roll one of their unspent hit die to recover more HP. Any lingering injury on the creature has its time reduced by 8 hours if the creature chose to expend a hit die.

You can create additional healing poultices by expending a spell slot of 1st level or higher. For any spell slot of 2nd level or higher expended during creation, the healing poultice you produce increases its healing by {@dice 1d8} and any lingering injuries time is reduced by an additional 4 hours for every level after 1st.

subclassFeature.name: Leech Siphon
entries: At 6th level, you have learned to immediately utilize the energy you siphon with your Witch Siphon feature. Every time you deal damage with your Witch Siphon, you gain TempHP equal to the damage you dealt.

subclassFeature.name: Health Harvest
entries: At 14th level, you can take the remnants of life remaining on any corpses you harvest with your Wicked Harvest and turn them into life usable by you and your allies. You may divy the results of the Wicked Harvest to recover hit die between you and your acolytes as if a hit die was a single 1st level spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Life Transfusion
entries: At 20th level, you are a conduit for life as much as you are one for magic. You are able to use your Wiccan Transposition to transfer hit die between two willing creatures touching you, keeping the die the same. This is undone when either creature takes a long rest.

You are also able to use this to curse your foes. When a creature is within 5 feet of you, you can force them to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, you swap your HP value with theirs. Any Hit Points that you or your target would gain beyond your or their maximum is given to you or them as temporary hit points. You can do this once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Chronurgy Magic
entries: Focusing on the manipulation of time, those who follow the Chronurgy tradition learn to alter the pace of reality to their liking. Using the ramping of anticipatory dunamis energy, these mages can bend the flow of time as adroitly as a skilled musician plays an instrument, lending themselves and their allies an advantage in the blink of an eye.

subclassFeature.name: Chronal Shift
entries: {@i 2nd-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

You can magically exert limited control over the flow of time around a creature. As a reaction, after you or a creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can add or subtract your Intelligence modifier to the roll (your choice) as you speed up or slow down the target to assist or hinder them.
You can use this ability a number of times per long rest equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Temporal Awareness
entries: {@i 2nd-level Chronurgy Magic feature}
You can add your Intelligence modifier to your initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Momentary Stasis
entries: {@i 6th-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

As an action, you can magically force a Large or smaller creature you can see within 60 feet of you to make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. Unless the saving throw is a success, the creature is encased in a field of magical energy until the end of your next turn or until the creature takes any damage. While encased in this way, the creature is {@condition Incapacitated|phb} and has a speed of 0.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Abeyance
entries: {@i 10th-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

When you cast a spell using a spell slot of 4th level or lower, you can condense the spell's magic into a mote. The spell is frozen in time at the moment of casting and held within a gray bead for 1 hour. This bead is a Tiny object with AC 15 and 1 hit point, and it is immune to poison and psychic damage. When the duration ends, or if the bead is destroyed, it vanishes in a flash of light, and the spell is lost.

A creature holding the bead can use its action to release the spell within, whereupon the bead disappears. The spell uses your spell attack bonus and save DC, and the spell treats the creature who released it as the caster for all other purposes.
Once you create a bead with this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Convergent Future
entries: {@i 14th-level Chronurgy Magic feature}

You can peer through possible futures and magically pull one of them into events around you, ensuring a particular outcome. When you or a creature you can see within 60 feet of you makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a saving throw, you can use your reaction to ignore the die roll and decide whether the number rolled is the minimum needed to succeed or one less than that number (your choice).
When you use this feature, you gain one level of {@condition Exhaustion|phb}. Only by finishing a long rest can you remove a level of {@condition Exhaustion|phb} gained in this way.

subclassFeature.name: Graviturgy Magic
entries: Understanding and mastering the forces that draw bodies of matter together or drive them apart, the students of the Graviturgy arcane tradition learn to further bend and manipulate the violent energy of gravity to their benefit, and the terrible detriment of their enemies.

subclassFeature.name: Adjust Density
entries: {@i 2nd-level Graviturgy Magic feature}

As an action, you can magically alter the weight of one object or creature you can see within 30 feet of you. If a creature, it makes a Charisma save against the effect. The object or creature must be Large or smaller. The target's weight is halved or doubled for up to 1 minute or until your {@status concentration} ends (as if you were concentrating on a spell).

While the weight of a creature is halved by this effect, the creature's speed increases by 10 feet, it can jump twice as far as normal, and it has disadvantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws. While the weight of a creature is doubled by this effect, the creature's speed is reduced by 10 feet, and it has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
Upon reaching 10th level in this class, you can target an object or a creature that is Huge or smaller.

subclassFeature.name: Gravity Well
entries: {@i 6th-level Graviturgy Magic feature}

You've learned how to manipulate gravity around a living being: whenever you cast a spell on a creature, you can move the target 5 feet to an unoccupied space of your choice if the target is willing to move, the spell hits it with an attack, or it fails a saving throw against the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Violent Attraction
entries: {@i 10th-level Graviturgy Magic feature}

When another creature that you can see within 60 feet of you hits with a weapon attack, you can use your reaction to increase the attack's velocity, causing the attack's target to take an extra {@damage 1d10} damage of the weapon's type.
Alternatively, if a creature within 60 feet of you takes damage from a fall, you can use your reaction to increase the fall's damage by {@dice 2d10}.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Event Horizon
entries: {@i 14th-level Graviturgy Magic feature}

As an action, you can magically emit a powerful field of gravitational energy that tugs at other creatures for up to 1 minute or until your concentration ends (as if you were concentrating on a spell). For the duration, whenever a creature hostile to you starts its turn within 30 feet of you, it must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 2d10} bludgeoning damage, and its speed is reduced to 0 until the start of its next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage, and every foot it moves this turn costs 2 extra feet of movement.
Once you use this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest or until you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher on it.

subclassFeature.name: School of Abjuration
entries: The School of Abjuration emphasizes magic that blocks, banishes, or protects. Detractors of this school say that its tradition is about denial, negation rather than positive assertion. You understand, however, that ending harmful effects, protecting the weak, and banishing evil influences is anything but a philosophical void. It is a proud and respected vocation.

Called abjurers, members of this school are sought when baleful spirits require exorcism, when important locations must be guarded against magical spying, and when portals to other planes of existence must be closed.

subclassFeature.name: Abjuration Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy an abjuration spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose an {@filter Abjuration spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=A}, you may choose an additional Abjuration spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Ward
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can weave magic around yourself for protection. When you cast an {@filter abjuration spell of 1st level or higher|spells|school=A|level=!0}, you can simultaneously use a strand of the spell's magic to create a magical ward on yourself that lasts until you finish a long rest. The ward has a hit point maximum equal to twice your wizard level + your Intelligence modifier. Whenever you take damage, the ward takes the damage instead. If this damage reduces the ward to 0 hit points, you take any remaining damage.

While the ward has 0 hit points, it can't absorb damage, but its magic remains. Whenever you cast an {@filter abjuration spell of 1st level or higher|spells|school=A|level=!0}, the ward regains a number of hit points equal to twice the level of the spell.
Once you create the ward, you can't create it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Projected Ward
entries: Starting at 6th level, when a creature that you can see within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to cause your Arcane Ward to absorb that damage. If this damage reduces the ward to 0 hit points, the warded creature takes any remaining damage.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Abjuration
entries: Beginning at 10th level, when you cast an abjuration spell that requires you to make an ability check as a part of casting that spell (as in {@spell counterspell} and {@spell dispel magic}), you add your proficiency bonus to that ability check.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Resistance
entries: Starting at 14th level, you have advantage on saving throws against spells.
Furthermore, you have resistance against the damage of spells.

subclassFeature.name: School of Conjuration
entries: As a conjurer, you favor spells that produce objects and creatures out of thin air. You can conjure billowing clouds of killing fog or summon creatures from elsewhere to fight on your behalf. As your mastery grows, you learn spells of transportation and can teleport yourself across vast distances, even to other planes of existence, in an instant.

subclassFeature.name: Conjuration Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a conjuration spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose a {@filter Conjuration spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=C}, you may choose an additional Conjuration spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Minor Conjuration
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you select this school, you can use your action to conjure up an inanimate object in your hand or on the ground in an unoccupied space that you can see within 10 feet of you. This object can be no larger than 3 feet on a side and weigh no more than 10 pounds, and its form must be that of a nonmagical object that you have seen. The object is visibly magical, radiating dim light out to 5 feet.
The object disappears after 1 hour, when you use this feature again, if it takes any damage, or if it deals any damage.

subclassFeature.name: Benign Transposition
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your action to teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see. Alternatively, you can choose a space within range that is occupied by a Small or Medium creature. If that creature is willing, you both teleport, swapping places.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest or you cast a conjuration spell of 1st level or higher.

subclassFeature.name: Focused Conjuration
entries: Beginning at 10th level, while you are concentrating on a conjuration spell, your concentration can't be broken as a result of taking damage.

subclassFeature.name: Durable Summons
entries: Starting at 14th level, any creature that you summon or create with a conjuration spell has 30 temporary hit points.

subclassFeature.name: School of Divination
entries: The counsel of a diviner is sought by royalty and commoners alike, for all seek a clearer understanding of the past, present, and future. As a diviner, you strive to part the veils of space, time, and consciousness so that you can see clearly. You work to master spells of discernment, remote viewing, supernatural knowledge, and foresight.

subclassFeature.name: Divination Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a divination spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose a {@filter Divination spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=D}, you may choose an additional Divination spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Portent
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you choose this school, glimpses of the future begin to press in on your awareness. When you finish a long rest, roll two {@dice d20}s and record the numbers rolled. You can replace any attack roll, saving throw, or ability check made by you or a creature that you can see with one of these foretelling rolls. You must choose to do so before the roll, and you can replace a roll in this way only once per turn.
Each foretelling roll can be used only once. When you finish a long rest, you lose any unused foretelling rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Expert Divination
entries: Beginning at 6th level, casting divination spells comes so easily to you that it expends only a fraction of your spellcasting efforts. When you cast a {@filter divination spell of 2nd level or higher|spells|school=D} using a spell slot, you regain one expended spell slot. The slot you regain must be of a level lower than the spell you cast and can't be higher than 5th level.

subclassFeature.name: The Third Eye
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use your action to increase your powers of perception. When you do so, choose one of the following benefits, which lasts until you are {@condition Incapacitated|phb} or you take a short or long rest. You can't use the feature again until you finish a rest.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Ethereal Sight
entries: You can see into the Ethereal Plane within 60 feet of you.

entries.name: Greater Comprehension
entries: You can read any language.

entries.name: See Invisibility
entries: You can see {@condition Invisible|phb} creatures and objects within 10 feet of you that are within line of sight.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Portent
entries: Starting at 14th level, the visions in your dreams intensify and paint a more accurate picture in your mind of what is to come. You roll three {@dice d20}s for your Portent feature, rather than two.

subclassFeature.name: School of Enchantment
entries: As a member of the School of Enchantment, you have honed your ability to magically entrance and beguile other people and monsters. Some enchanters are peacemakers who bewitch the violent to lay down their arms and charm the cruel into showing mercy. Others are tyrants who magically bind the unwilling into their service. Most enchanters fall somewhere in between.

subclassFeature.name: Enchantment Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy an enchantment spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose an {@filter Enchantment spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=E}, you may choose an additional Enchantment spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Hypnotic Gaze
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you choose this school, your soft words and enchanting gaze can magically enthrall another creature. As an action, choose one creature that you can see within 5 feet of you. If the target can see or hear you, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your wizard spell save DC or be {@condition Charmed|phb} by you until the end of your next turn. The {@condition Charmed|phb} creature's speed drops to 0, and the creature is {@condition Incapacitated|phb} and visibly dazed.

On subsequent turns, you can use your action to maintain this effect, extending its duration until the end of your next turn. However, the effect ends if you move more than 5 feet away from the creature, if the creature can neither see nor hear you, or if the creature takes damage.
Once the effect ends, or if the creature succeeds on its initial saving throw against this effect, you can't use this feature on that creature again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Instinctive Charm
entries: Beginning at 6th level, when a creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to divert the attack, provided that another creature is within the attack's range. The attacker must make a Wisdom saving throw against your wizard spell save DC. On a failed save, the attacker must target the creature that is closest to it, not including you or itself. If multiple creatures are closest, the attacker chooses which one to target. On a successful save, you can't use this feature on the attacker again until you finish a long rest.
You must choose to use this feature before knowing whether the attack hits or misses. Creatures that can't be {@condition Charmed|phb} are immune to this effect.

subclassFeature.name: Split Enchantment
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you cast an enchantment spell of 1st level or higher that targets only one creature, you can have it target a second creature.

subclassFeature.name: Alter Memories
entries: At 14th level, you gain the ability to make a creature unaware of your magical influence on it. When you cast an enchantment spell to charm one or more creatures, you can alter one creature's understanding so that it remains unaware of being {@condition Charmed|phb}.

Additionally, once before the spell expires, you can use your action to try to make the chosen creature forget some of the time it spent {@condition Charmed|phb}. The creature must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw against your wizard spell save DC or lose a number of hours of its memories equal to 1 + your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1). You can make the creature forget less time, and the amount of time can't exceed the duration of your enchantment spell.

subclassFeature.name: School of Evocation
entries: You focus your study on magic that creates powerful elemental effects such as bitter cold, searing flame, rolling thunder, crackling lightning, and burning acid. Some evokers find employment in military forces, serving as artillery to blast enemy armies from afar. Others use their spectacular power to protect the weak, while some seek their own gain as bandits, adventurers, or aspiring tyrants.

subclassFeature.name: Evocation Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy an evocation spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose an {@filter Evocation spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=V}, you may choose an additional Evocation spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Sculpt Spells
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can create pockets of relative safety within the effects of your evocation spells. When you cast an evocation spell that affects other creatures that you can see, you can choose a number of them equal to 1 + the spell's level. The chosen creatures automatically succeed on their saving throws against the spell, and they take no damage if they would normally take half damage on a successful save.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Cantrip
entries: Starting at 6th level, your damaging cantrips affect even creatures that avoid the brunt of the effect. When a creature succeeds on a saving throw against your cantrip, the creature takes half the cantrip's damage (if any) but suffers no additional effect from the cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Evocation
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of any wizard evocation spell you cast.

subclassFeature.name: Overchannel
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can increase the power of your simpler spells. When you cast a wizard spell of 1st through 5th-level that deals damage, you can deal maximum damage with that spell.

The first time you do so, you suffer no adverse effect. If you use this feature again before you finish a long rest, you take {@damage 2d12} necrotic damage for each level of the spell, immediately after you cast it. Each time you use this feature again before finishing a long rest, the necrotic damage per spell level increases by {@dice 1d12}. This damage ignores resistance and immunity.

subclassFeature.name: School of Illusion
entries: You focus your studies on magic that dazzles the senses, befuddles the mind, and tricks even the wisest folk. Your magic is subtle, but the illusions crafted by your keen mind make the impossible seem real. Some illusionists—including many gnome wizards—are benign tricksters who use their spells to entertain. Others are more sinister masters of deception, using their illusions to frighten and fool others for their personal gain.

subclassFeature.name: Illusion Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy an illusion spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose an {@filter Illusion Spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=I}, you may choose an additional Illusion spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Minor Illusion
entries: When you choose this school at 2nd level, you learn the {@spell minor illusion} cantrip. If you already know this cantrip, you learn a different wizard cantrip of your choice. The cantrip doesn't count against your number of cantrips known.
When you cast {@spell minor illusion}, you can create both a sound and an image with a single casting of the spell.

subclassFeature.name: Malleable Illusions
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you cast an illusion spell that has a duration of 1 minute or longer, you can use your action to change the nature of that illusion (using the spell's normal parameters for the illusion), provided that you can see the illusion.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Step
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can create an illusory duplicate of yourself as an instant, almost instinctual reaction to danger. When a creature makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to interpose the illusory duplicate between the attacker and yourself. The attack automatically misses you, then the illusion dissipates.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Illusory Reality
entries: By 14th level, you have learned the secret of weaving shadow magic into your illusions to give them a semireality. When you cast an illusion spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose one inanimate, nonmagical object that is part of the illusion and make that object real. You can do this on your turn as a bonus action while the spell is ongoing. The object remains real for 1 minute. For example, you can create an illusion of a bridge over a chasm and then make it real long enough for your allies to cross.
The object can't deal damage or otherwise directly harm anyone.

subclassFeature.name: School of Necromancy
entries: The School of Necromancy explores the cosmic forces of life, death, and undeath. As you focus your studies in this tradition, you learn to manipulate the energy that animates all living things. As you progress, you learn to sap the life force from a creature as your magic destroys its body, transforming that vital energy into magical power you can manipulate.

Most people see necromancers as menacing, or even villainous, due to the close association with death. Not all necromancers are evil, but the forces they manipulate are considered taboo by many societies.

subclassFeature.name: Grim Harvest
entries: At 2nd level, you gain the ability to reap life energy from creatures you kill with your spells. Once per turn when you kill one or more creatures with a spell of 1st level or higher, you regain hit points equal to twice the spell's level, or three times its level if the spell belongs to the {@filter School of Necromancy|spells|school=N}. You don't gain this benefit for killing constructs or undead.

subclassFeature.name: Necromancy Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a necromancy spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose an {@filter Necromancy spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=N}, you may choose an additional Necromancy spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Undead Thralls
entries: At 6th level, you add the {@spell animate dead} spell to your spellbook if it is not there already. When you cast {@spell animate dead}, you can target one additional corpse or pile of bones, creating another zombie or skeleton, as appropriate.
Whenever you create an undead using a necromancy spell, it has additional benefits:

items: The creature's hit point maximum is increased by an amount equal to your wizard level.
The creature adds your proficiency bonus to its weapon damage rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Inured to Undeath
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you have resistance to necrotic damage, and your hit point maximum can't be reduced. You have spent so much time dealing with undead and the forces that animate them that you have become inured to some of their worst effects.

subclassFeature.name: Command Undead
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use magic to bring undead under your control, even those created by other wizards. As an action, you can choose one undead that you can see within 60 feet of you. That creature must make a Charisma saving throw against your wizard spell save DC. If it succeeds, you can't use this feature on it again. If it fails, it becomes friendly to you and obeys your commands until you use this feature again.

Intelligent undead are harder to control in this way. If the target has an Intelligence of 8 or higher, it has advantage on the saving throw. If it fails the saving throw and has an Intelligence of 12 or higher, it can repeat the saving throw at the end of every hour until it succeeds and breaks free.

subclassFeature.name: School of Transmutation
entries: You are a student of spells that modify energy and matter. To you, the world is not a fixed thing, but eminently mutable, and you delight in being an agent of change. You wield the raw stuff of creation and learn to alter both physical forms and mental qualities. Your magic gives you the tools to become a smith on reality's forge.

Some transmuters are tinkerers and pranksters, turning people into toads and transforming copper into silver for fun and occasional profit. Others pursue their magical studies with deadly seriousness, seeking the power of the gods to make and destroy worlds.

subclassFeature.name: Minor Alchemy
entries: Starting at 2nd level when you select this school, you can temporarily alter the physical properties of one nonmagical object, changing it from one substance into another. You perform a special alchemical procedure on one object composed entirely of wood, stone (but not a gemstone), iron, copper, or silver, transforming it into a different one of those materials. For each 10 minutes you spend performing the procedure, you can transform up to 1 cubic foot of material. After 1 hour, or until you lose your concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell), the material reverts to its original substance.

subclassFeature.name: Transmutation Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a transmutation spell into your spellbook is halved.

Additionally, once per level up, when you are choosing what spells to learn, if you choose a {@filter Transmutation spell|spells|class=Wizard|school=T}, you may choose an additional Transmutation spell to learn from the Wizard spell list. This spell does not count against the number of spells you can learn for your level up.

subclassFeature.name: Transmuter's Stone
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can spend 8 hours creating a transmuter's stone that stores transmutation magic. You can benefit from the stone yourself or give it to another creature. A creature gains a benefit of your choice as long as the stone is in the creature's possession. When you create the stone, choose the benefit from the following options:

items: Darkvision out to a range of 60 feet, as described in chapter 8.
An increase to speed of 10 feet while the creature is unencumbered.
Proficiency in Constitution saving throws.
Resistance to acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage (your choice whenever you choose this benefit).

entries: Each time you cast a transmutation spell of 1st level or higher, you can change the effect of your stone if the stone is on your person.
If you create a new transmuter's stone, the previous one ceases to function.

subclassFeature.name: Shapechanger
entries: At 10th level, you add the {@spell polymorph} spell to your spellbook, if it is not there already. You can cast {@spell polymorph} without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can target only yourself and transform into a {@filter beast whose challenge rating is 1 or lower|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&1]|type=beast|miscellaneous=!swarm}.
Once you cast {@spell polymorph} in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest, though you can still cast it normally using an available spell slot.

subclassFeature.name: Master Transmuter
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your action to consume the reserve of transmutation magic stored within your transmuter's stone in a single burst. When you do so, choose one of the following effects. Your transmuter's stone is destroyed and can't be remade until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Major Transformation
entries: You can transmute one nonmagical object—no larger than a 5-foot cube—into another nonmagical object of similar size and mass and of equal or lesser value. You must spend 10 minutes handling the object to transform it.

entries.name: Panacea
entries: You remove all curses, diseases, and poisons affecting a creature that you touch with the transmuter's stone. The creature also regains all its hit points.

entries.name: Restore Life
entries: You cast the {@spell raise dead} spell on a creature you touch with the transmuter's stone, without expending a spell slot or needing to have the spell in your spellbook.

entries.name: Restore Youth
entries: You touch the transmuter's stone to a willing creature, and that creature's apparent age is reduced by {@dice 3d10} years, to a minimum of 13 years. This effect doesn't extend the creature's lifespan.

subclassFeature.name: Bladesinging
entries: Bladesingers master a tradition of wizardry that incorporates swordplay and dance. Originally created by elves, this tradition has been adopted by non-elf practitioners, who honor and expand on the elven ways.

In combat, a bladesinger uses a series of intricate, elegant maneuvers that fend off harm and allow the bladesinger to channel magic into devastating attacks and a cunning defense. Many who have observed a bladesinger at work remember the display as one of the more beautiful experiences in their life, a glorious dance accompanied by a singing blade.

subclassFeature.name: Bladesinger Styles
entries: From its inception as a martial and magical art, Bladesinging has been tied to the sword, more specifically the longsword. Yet many generations of study gave rise to various styles of Bladesinging based on the melee weapon employed. The techniques of these styles are passed from master to students in small schools, some of which have a building dedicated to instruction. Even the newest styles are hundreds of years old, but are still taught by their original creators due to the long lives of elves. Most schools of Bladesinging are in Evermeet or Evereska. One was started in Myth Drannor, but the city's destruction has scattered those students who survived.

Styles of Bladesinging are broadly categorized based on the type of weapon employed, and each is associated with a category of animal. Within that style are specializations named after specific animal types, based on the types of spells employed, the techniques of the master, and the particular weapon used. Bladesingers who apprentice to a master typically get a tattoo of their chosen style's animal. Some bladesingers learn multiple styles and bear many tattoos, wearing a warning on their skin of their deadly skills.

entries.name: Cat
entries: Styles that employ a sword belong to this family. The lion style, the eldest, trains practitioners in the use of the longsword and doesn't favor any particular type of spells. Leopard style focuses on the shortsword and spells of illusion and stealth. Red tiger, a style just three centuries old, has its bladesingers using the scimitar in a whirling dance of defense from which they launch into sudden leaps and attacks.

entries.name: Bird
entries: Styles that focus on the use of a hafted weapon, such as an axe or hammer, have been grouped together as bird styles, yet they vary wildly. All relatively new styles, they use weapons not typically favored by elves. Eagle-style bladesingers use small handaxes, and many maneuvers in the style focus on fluid ways to throw the weapon and draw a new one. Raven style uses a war pick, and spells associated with it grant the bladesinger more agility in combat.

entries.name: Snake
entries: Practitioners of these styles use a flail, chain, or whip. Viper style uses a whip, despite its inelegance as a weapon, and has almost as long a history as the lion style. Its masters punctuate their bladesong with a stunningly rapid rhythm of whip cracks, which can keep many foes at bay and allow the bladesinger space to cast the cruel spells of poison and disease favored by the style.

subclassFeature.name: Bladesong
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can invoke a secret elven magic called the Bladesong, provided you aren't wearing medium or heavy armor or using a shield. It graces you with supernatural speed, agility, and focus.

You can use a bonus action to start the Bladesong, which lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are {@condition Incapacitated|phb}, if you don medium or heavy armor or a shield, or if you use two hands to make an attack with a weapon. You can also dismiss Bladesong at any time you choose (no action required).
While your bladesong is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain a bonus to your AC equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1).
Your walking speed increases by 10 feet.
You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) checks.
You gain a bonus to any Constitution saving throws you make to maintain concentration on a spell. The bonus equals your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1).

entries: You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Training in War and Song (Bladesinging)
entries: When you adopt this tradition at 2nd level, you gain proficiency with light armor, and you gain proficiency with one type of one-handed melee weapon of your choice.
You also gain proficiency in the {@skill Performance} skill if you don't already have it.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Song of Defense
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you can direct your magic to absorb damage while your bladesong is active. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to expend one spell slot and reduce that damage to you by an amount equal to five times the spell's slot level.

subclassFeature.name: Song of Victory
entries: Starting at 14th level, you add your Intelligence modifier (minimum of +1) to the damage of your melee weapon attacks while your Bladesong is active.

subclassFeature.name: Order of Scribes
entries: Magic of the book-that's what many folk call wizardry. The name is apt, given how much time wizards spend poring over tomes and penning theories about the nature of magic. It's rare to see wizards traveling without books and scrolls sprouting from their bags, and a wizard would go to great lengths to plumb an archive of ancient knowledge.

Among wizards, the Order of Scribes is the most bookish. It takes many forms in different worlds, but its primary mission is the same everywhere: recording magical discoveries so that wizardry can flourish. And while all wizards value spellbooks, a wizard in the Order of Scribes magically awakens their book, turning it into a trusted companion. All wizards study books, but a wizardly scribe talks to theirs!

subclassFeature.name: Awakened Spellbook
entries: {@i 2nd-level Order of Scribes feature}
Using specially prepared inks and ancient incantations passed down by your wizardly order, you have awakened an arcane sentience within your spellbook.
While you are holding the book, it grants you the following benefits:

items: You can use the book as a spellcasting focus for your wizard spells.

When you cast a wizard spell with a spell slot, you can temporarily replace its damage type with a type that appears in another spell in your spellbook, which magically alters the spell's formula for this casting only. The latter spell must be of the same level as the spell slot you expend.

When you cast a wizard spell as a ritual, you can use the spell's normal casting time, rather than adding 10 minutes to it. Once you use this benefit, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries: If necessary, you can replace the book over the course of a short rest by using your Wizardly Quill to write arcane sigils in a blank book or a magic spellbook to which you're attuned. At the end of the rest, your spellbook's consciousness is summoned into the new book, which the consciousness transforms into your spellbook, along with all its spells. If the previous book still existed somewhere, all the spells vanish from its pages.

subclassFeature.name: Wizardly Quill
entries: {@i 2nd-level Order of Scribes feature}
As a bonus action, you can magically create a Tiny quill in your free hand. The magic quill has the following properties:

items: The quill doesn't require ink. When you write with it, it produces ink in a color of your choice on the writing surface. This ink's magical property is its erasability, making it ineffective for use in spell or scroll creation.
